* Note that this is not a complete list yet, it will grow as we advance through
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
Curriculum
The following resources is the course curriculum.
Your exam project should demonstrate the use of topics from this curriculum and you will furthermore be asked questions from this curriculum at the oral exam.

* Note that this is not a complete list yet, it will grow as we advance through the elective.

Node.js

  • Node.js Playlist
  • Node.js v4.2.4 Documentation
    • About this Documentation
    • Synopsis
    • Buffer
    • File System
    • Global Objects
    • Modules
    • Path
    • Readline
    • Stream
    • Timers
    • URL
    • util

Express.js

  • Building a Website with Node.js and Express.js
  • Writing middleware for use in Express apps
  • Using middleware
  • 4.x API

Websockets

  • Websockets Playlist

REST API

  • RESTful Service Best Practices

MongoDB

  • http://expressjs.com/en/guide/database-integration.html#mongo

item.title: Day 1 - Introduction
item.description:
Time: 5/2-2016, 08:30 - 13:20

In this first class you will get introduced to what we are going to work on the next 14 weeks.

You will also get an introduction to the Node.js server, you will download and install the server, and you will create
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
Time: 5/2-2016, 08:30 - 13:20

In this first class you will get introduced to what we are going to work on the next 14 weeks.

You will also get an introduction to the Node.js server, you will download and install the server, and you will create your first webserver and webpage. This webserver will run locally on your computer and it will be accessable on your local network for everybody.

Objectives:

  • An overview of what will be covered in the next 14 weeks.
    • Curriculum
    • Exam and Mandatory Assignments
  • Introduction to and installation of Node.js.
  • Make your first Webserver and a Hello World web page.

Tools:

  • Git
  • Sublime Text 3
  • Node.js

Exercises:

  • Install git
  • The Command Line Crash Course
  • Introduction to the Mac OS X Command Li
  • Unix/Linux Command Reference
  • My first Webserver (used as "follow along" example in this class)

Code on Github: 

  • keanodejs
  • Todays examples

item.title: Day 4 - Javascript
item.description:
Time: 22/2-2016, 13:20 - 15:45 &
Time: 25/2-2016, 13:20 - 15:00

In this class we will be together with the students from the Angular.js elective.

Notice that the time for this class is different than the normal friday classes

Place: L37, 1-A-08 &
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
Time: 22/2-2016, 13:20 - 15:45 &
Time: 25/2-2016, 13:20 - 15:00

In this class we will be together with the students from the Angular.js elective.

Notice that the time for this class is different than the normal friday classes

Place: L37, 1-A-08 & 1-A-09

Today we will cover the basics of the Javascript language, and we will focus on the EcmaScript 5 standart.

The three semesters of Java Programming you have had so far will make it relative easy for you to learn a new language, including Javascript. And like you would if you where trying to learn C++ og C#, you will spend a little time to get to know the similarities and differences between what you already know and Javascript.

Javascript is often seen as almost similar to Java, and that makes most programmers just start using it before learning it. But as it turns out, it is quite different in many ways and therefore it is good to spend a little time to understand it before you just jump into it.

And this is what we will do today.

Objectives:

Literature:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide
  • http://eclipsesource.com/blogs/2013/07/05/private-members-in-javascript/

Tools:

  • Loupe

Videos:

  • Crockford on JavaScript – Chapter 2: And Then There Was JavaScript

Exercises:

  • basicjavascriptexamplesandexercises
  • Function Exercises
  • Object Exercises
  • Inheritance Exercises
  • Javascript øvelse
    • lav javascript der indsætter dato i en tabel ala teaching schedule og som selv opdaterer hvis en tr bliver flyttet eller slettet.

Code on Github:

  • Materials from today

item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
Time: 11/3-2016, 08:30 - 13:20

Prequisite
Before the start of this day 6 class, you should have completed the online Lynda.com tutorial on

  • Building a Website with Node.js and Express.js (2h 46m)

If you have not created a free account yet you can do it by following these steps.

ExpressJS is maybe the most used Module on the Node.js platform, and today we will work with that.

Objectives:

Literature:

NPM
Getting Started 01- 12
package.json
Unpublish
Express
Express 4.x Api Documentation
Express Guide Routing
Express Guide Middleware
Express Guide Error Handling
Tutorials:

Getting started:

Installing
Hello world example
Basic routing tutorial
Serving static files in Express
Exercises:

Publish a Module to NPM

Code on Github:

Materials from today

item.title: Day 8 - Websockets
item.description:
Today we will be working with sockets. We will create a chat server, and we will use the socket functionality to get feeds from Twitter based on tags pushed to our websites.

For inspiration we will also look at some more advanced ways of using sockets, which could be the
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
Today we will be working with sockets. We will create a chat server, and we will use the socket functionality to get feeds from Twitter based on tags pushed to our websites.

For inspiration we will also look at some more advanced ways of using sockets, which could be the basis of your exam projects.

Prequisite

Look through the tutorials in this Lynda.com Playlist (23m 17s).

Topics to be covered

  • Needle

Exercises

http://www.tutorialindustry.com/nodejs-socketio-chat-application-tutorial

item.title: How To Create A Lynda.com Account
item.description:
Be at KEA, Lygten 37.
Sign in to the network (like you normally do)
Go to: http://iplogin.lynda.com/
Sign up using your KEA-mail and password.
Have fun learning!
At this stage you can log in to Lynda.com from any network (from home e.g.).
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové

item.title: #1 Tutorial: My first Webserver
item.description:
In this forst tutorial you are going to create a webserver with a webpage and deploy it to an online host. So the result will be your first, public accessable Node.js website.

You will be guided through installing Node.js on your computer, creating a webserver on your Node.
item.dc:creator: Claus Bové
item.content:encoded:
In this forst tutorial you are going to create a webserver with a webpage and deploy it to an online host. So the result will be your first, public accessable Node.js website.

You will be guided through installing Node.js on your computer, creating a webserver on your Node.js installation. This webserver will be accessable to anyone on the local network you are currently on. Then you will create an account at Heroku, a host, where you will be deploying your new website. At the end you will be deploying the website to Azure and you will have your first Node.js public accesable website up and running.

Installing Node.js

First of all you need to download and install Node.js. The Installations is pretty straight forward, but if you need it, guides kan be found here:

  • Installing Node.js on a Mac
  • Installing Node.js on Windows
  • Installing Node.js on Linux

To test if your installation went ok, and that you have Node.js on your computer, open the console and type:

node --version

Then you should see something like this:

node --version
v0.12.7

The version number could differ in your case. If you do not see this, something went wrong in the installation process, and try to install Node.js again.

Create a local Webserver

Now let´s create our first server. Create a folder and in it a file called server.js, containing the following code.

    var http = require('http');
    http.createServer(function (req, res) {
      res.writeHead(200, {'Content-Type': 'text/plain'});
      res.end('Hello World\n');
    }).listen(3000);

Start the server from the console by browsing to the folder you just created and type:

   node server.js

Now open your browser and type in the url: http://localhost:3000/

If what you made now is indeed a webserver, and not just a document saying “Hello World”, you should be able to access this site from you phone or another computer.

Get the ip-address of you machine (the server) and then make sure that your phone is on the same network as your computer (the server). Type in 10.108.10.86:3000 (this is my ip, you should of cause use yours).

Hopefully you see this, otherwise: “are your devices on the same network” ?

(heavily inspired by http://howtonode.org/deploy-blog-to-heroku)
